newsitem.title: BELGIUM: LERNOUT SEES INSTANT BERKELEY EPS LIFT.
newsitem.headline: LERNOUT SEES INSTANT BERKELEY EPS LIFT.

text.p: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products, the Nasdaq-listed Belgian speech technology firm, expects profits from U.S. Berkeley Speech Technologies(BST) to lift its earnings per share (EPS) immediately.

Pre-tax EPS should get a notable boost from text-to-speech company Berkeley's 40 percent operating margin. "From this moment," a L&H spokeswoman said, when asked when the contribution would become visible in L&H's profits.
Berkeley's revenues would grow to $6.0 million to $8.0 million in the coming year, she said, from $5 million in the year to September 1996.
She added L&H expected to have earned back the $15.5 million cash outlay for Berkeley "in a few years."
L&H expected the purchase to create the conditions for it to become one of the key players in the text-to-speech market.

"The combination of BST's successful and dedicated consumer market approach for text-to-speech with one of the market leaders in speech technologies, L&H, should result in a formidable, competitive player in the speech-to-text market, BST chairwoman Elisabeth Peters said in a statement issued by L&H.

L&H's EPS swung to a $0.08 profit after the first nine months of 1997 from $1.43 loss in the same 1996 period. Third quarter revenues jumped to $7.25 million from $2.09 million in the same year-ago period.

The company, set up in 1987, currently employs some 500 people. Its technology allows computers to recognise speech automatically, transform computer text into speech, or convert speech into digital signals.
It is available in a number of languages, including Dutch, French, German, Italian and Korean.
